chunks.lyrics: h - hammer on b - Bend e.g.: 10b(12) = bend 1 tone
, - slight palm mute () - ghost note, sustained note
Most of the times, two (-) are equal to one 8th note (this may vary
when I have to transcribe fret numbers above 9 ; in these case,
The numbers above the measures are the time signatures.
As always, I'm not claiming that this is THE perfect tab. It's
simply my interpretation of the song, or how I like to play it.
Of course, any suggestions, improvements or comments are welcome.
By the way, the first guitar (Bryssling) is panned in the left speaker
and the second guitar (Karlsson) is panned in the right speaker.
(For some riffs that don't require the high strings, I sometimes
merged both guitars in one because the low strings are similar).
(this applies for everytime there are two staves)
RIFF 1 (play the whole thing 2x and the first 2 bars 1 more time)
Often this riff follows a simple pattern (e.g.: in bar 3,4,7,8,etc.)
which consists of 8th, 8th, 16th, 16th, 8th notes. The frets above 9
make it hard to follow, but just listen to the song for an exact rythm.
4/4 (in spite of the size of certain bars, it's all in 4/4)
Then, play RIFF 1 (1x) but begin with the last two bars of it
(and then play the two first bars).
Then there's a 4 beats drum fill and...
The notes marked with an * are played in a triplet feel.
Listen to the CD for a better idea of the rythm.
A lot of effects on that one, but I'm not specialist in effects
For rythm, listen to the CD. The only indication I can give is the
(Same riff, I know, but p.m. changes)
Then play RIFF 6a 4x again, but at TEMPO=230.
Same as RIFF 5, but play bar 2 differently :
pick these notes in artificial harmonics.............
Then play the chorus again (RIFF 4a + RIFF 4b)
Then play the last bar of the intro
Then play the intro 4x, which you could also call outro now.

think you can find it yourself.
